before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"8mka0","text":"Our goal was to create a method for assessing the impact of changes in 3D contact on enhancer function. To achieve this, we developed CRISPRi of regulatory elements upon degron operation (CRUDO), a technique that combines dCas9-KRAB-mediated perturbations with targeted protein degradation using an auxin-inducible degron system. CRUDO offers versatility, allowing us to address various fundamental questions in gene regulation by employing different factors and target enhancer-promoter pairs for perturbation. In our specific case, we targeted RAD21, a subunit of the cohesin complex crucial for maintaining 3D genome architecture. However, CRDUO can easily be adapted according to a specific research questions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"akbc2","text":"Enhancers are key drivers of gene regulation thought to act via 3D physical interactions with the promoters of their target genes. However, genome-wide depletions of architectural proteins such as cohesin result in only limited changes in gene expression, despite a loss of contact domains and loops1-4. Consequently, the role of cohesin and 3D contacts in enhancer function remains debated5-7. Here, we developed CRISPRi of regulatory elements upon degron operation (CRUDO), a novel approach to measure how changes in contact frequency impact enhancer effects on target genes by perturbing enhancers with CRISPRi and measuring gene expression in the presence or absence of cohesin. We systematically perturbed all 1,039 candidate enhancers near five cohesin-dependent genes and identified 34 enhancer-gene regulatory interactions. Of 26 regulatory interactions with sufficient statistical power to evaluate cohesin dependence, 18 show cohesin-dependent effects. A decrease in enhancer-promoter contact frequency upon removal of cohesin is frequently accompanied by a decrease in the regulatory effect of the enhancer on gene expression, consistent with a contact-based model for enhancer function8-11. However, changes in contact frequency and regulatory effects on gene expression vary as a function of distance, with distal enhancers (e.g., \u003e50Kb) experiencing much larger changes than proximal ones (e.g., \u003c50Kb). Because most enhancers are located close to their target genes, these observations can explain how only a small subset of genes — those with strong distal enhancers — are sensitive to cohesin. Together, our results illuminate how 3D contacts, influenced by both cohesin and genomic distance, tune enhancer effects on gene expression.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":299,"length":3},{"style":"sup","offset":390,"length":3},{"style":"sup","offset":1197,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vugh","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ciplc","text":"Note: The list of authors for this protocol does not include all authors of the accompanying manuscript, only those who played a role in developing and executing the CRUDO method. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"d80lo","text":"General considerations for selection of a gene targets for CRUDO.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":65}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77egj","text":"To optimize experimental outcomes when applying CRUDO, we recommend selecting target genes with relatively high expression levels (e.g., RNA-seq TPM \u003e20). This is especially crucial if you anticipate perturbations to decrease target gene expression, ensuring good sensitivity and accuracy in measurements. Additionally, the duration of perturbation and protein degradation influences the choice of target genes. Since we measure mature mRNAs, there's a lag in observing effects, which may require longer perturbation and protein degradation periods for precise effect size measurements. However, logistical constraints or biological factors may limit extended durations. In such cases, selecting genes with short mRNA half-lives minimizes temporal delays in effect size measurement. In our case, we were restricted to a 6-hour cohesin degradation window, prompting the selection of genes exhibiting a reduction in expression after 6 hours of auxin treatment by at least -0.25 and -0.5 log2 fold change in RNA-seq and PRO-seq data. The reduction in RNA-seq indicates that the mRNA half-lives of these genes are short enough to identify changes after 6h of treatment. Depending on research objectives, other criteria may also be relevant. In our context, as we aimed to understand how changes in 3D contacts impact gene regulation, accordingly we chose genes showing decreased expression (as measured by PRO-seq) upon cohesin removal. Furthermore, we selected genes with diverse regulatory landscapes based on ABC-predicted enhancers spanning various linear genomic distances.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7u7st","text":"General considerations for selection of acellular model for CRUDO.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":66}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7puk8","text":"CRUDO is a versatile approach that is adaptable to address a range of questions concerning gene regulation. Consequently, the choice of a cellular model predominantly depends on the specific research question at hand. For instance, if investigating a particular disease or trait, selecting a cellular model relevant to the context becomes crucial. Conversely, if addressing amore fundamental research question, leveraging an existing cellular model may be beneficial, avoiding the need to create a new auxin-inducible or CRISPRi cell line. In general, when applying CRUDO, opting for a cell line receptive to engineering can significantly enhance efficiency, particularly for tasks such as virus delivery and perturbation strength.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b5ff2","text":"General considerations for selection of a CRUDO read-out.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":57}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bfhhp","text":"Similarly, the choice of read-out for CRUDO experiments depends on the specific research question. We have so far combined CRUDO with two different read-outs: RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization and cell sorting (FlowFISH11) or targeted Perturb-seq (TAP-seq12). ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":224,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":260,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69f10","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ln06","text":"A key advantage of CRUDO-FlowFISH (CRUDO-FF) is the precise measurement of each candidate element's effect on gene expression. This is achieved by analyzing thousands of single cells per gRNA, many gRNAs per element, and hundreds to thousands of negative control gRNAs in a single pooled experiment. Robust measurements are ensured by increasing both the number of gRNAs per element and the number of cells analyzed for each perturbation. Because CRUDO-FF uses cell sorting, the number of analyzed cells can be significantly higher, while sequencing costs are minimized as only the gRNAs from each sorting bin need to be sequenced. However, CRUDO-FF is limited to measuring one gene at a time. FlowFISH is recommended as the CRUDO readout due to its high sensitivity, particularly when analyzing changes in gene expression for a limited number of target genes (ideally, not more than five), and when screening numerous elements to benefit from the large number of cells that can be screened. For CRUDO-FF we use the PrimeFlow probesets and kit from Thermo Fisher Scientific (#88–18005).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2poqh","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7h24l","text":"Alternatively, CRUDO can be combined with TAP-seq (CRUDO-TAP) by performing single-cell RNA sequencing and amplifying the targets of interest. This targeted approach enhances measurement sensitivity and decreases sequencing costs compared to conventional whole transcriptome single-cell RNA-sequencing techniques. CRUDO-TAP is recommended when only perturbing a few elements (ideally less than 30) while aiming to understand their impact on many different genes. For CRUDO-TAP, the TAP-seq primer designing pipeline12 should be used to design primers for cDNA amplification of the genes of interest, typically including genes expressed within 1Mb of any gRNA in the library pool, housekeeping genes, and other genes specific to the screen.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":515,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"560fn","text":"Introduction to culturing of CRUDO cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":41}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2p7m7","text":"The HCT-116 cell line, HCT-116-RAD21-mAID-mClover1,13, serves as our cellular model and is puromycin, hygromycin, and neomycin resistant because these markers are present on the auxin-inducible cohesin degradation plasmids. Consequently, we relied on alternative selection markers whenever feasible. For most cell lines lacking these resistant markers, other constructs may function as suitable alternatives.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":49,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9sm4l","text":"Cell type-specific media.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8sjel","text":"Culture HEK293T cells (Takara, #632180) in DMEM media (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #11995065) supplemented with 10% HIFBS (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #10082147). Culture HCT-116 cells in McCoy’s 5A media (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #16600082) supplemented with 2mM L-glutamine (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 25030081), 100U/ml Penicillin with 100μg/ml Streptomycin (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #15140122), and 10% HIFBS.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1ufno","text":"Maintenance of cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ckh7r","text":"Maintain a confluency of 20-80% by splitting the cells every two days. Store the cells in an incubator at 37°C and 5% CO2.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5a85a","text":"Harvesting and passaging of cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adedb","text":"Harvest or passage the cells by aspirating the media, washing the adherent cells with PBS (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #10010023), and incubating the cells with trypsin (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #25200114) for 2 minutes. To quench the reaction, add fresh media on top and centrifuge the cells at 400g for 5 minutes. Resuspend the cells in fresh media for further use. Count the cells using a Countess cell counter. To do this, take 10µl of cells and mix with 10µl of trypan blue solution, then add 10µl of this mix to one chamber on a Countess slide.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"l4kp","text":"Plating HEK293T cells for virus production.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":43}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"auq4u","text":"To begin virus production, harvest, count, and plate 2.5 million HEK293T cells on a 10cm dish (VWR, #10062880) as described in the \"Culturing of CRUDO Cells\" section.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ab6a2","text":"Transfect HEK293T cells for virus production.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2k6gp","text":"24-hours post-plating, transfect the HEK293T cells with the following transfection reagents:","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1l80s","text":"-\t7.2μg of our transfer plasmid (expressing dCAS9-KRAB-BFP or gRNAs,  and a selectable marker between viral LTR sequences)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bp26r","text":"-\t5.4μg of psPAX2 (a lentiviral co-packaging plasmid, Addgene, #12260) ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f1t8m","text":"-\t2.16μg of pMD2.G (a lentiviral co-packaging plasmid, Addgene, #12259)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"taia","text":"-\t1,150μl Opti-MEM (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #31985070)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fuok8","text":"-\t35μl XtremeGene9 (MilliporeSigma, #6365787001) in 10ml of DMEM with10% HIFBS media. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bq8rm","text":"Combine the transfection reagents and incubate at room temperature for 15 minutes before adding the solution dropwise to the cells in HEK296T media. After 16 hours, exchange the media for fresh HEK296T media.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"82irj","text":"Harvest virus produced by HEK293T cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vv2e","text":"At 24 hours post-transfection, harvest the first batch of viral supernatant. Then add fresh HEK293T media to the cells. Store the viral supernatant at 4°C and harvest the viral supernatant again at 48 hours post-transfection.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"26ded","text":"Filter and concentrate the viral supernatant.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1nj6","text":"Combine the harvested virus supernatant for each construct, filter the supernatant using a vacuum-driven filtration system (MilliporeSigma, #SE1M003M00), and concentrate the virus 20X with centrifugal filters (MilliporeSigma #UFC910024).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5hlof","text":"Store the viral supernatant.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ekgn9","text":"Store the filtered and concentrated viral supernatant at 4°C unless the time before use exceeds two weeks. In that case, divide the virus into 1ml aliquots and snap freeze at -80°C.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1avt0","text":"Transducing HCT-116 cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b41ps","text":"Transduce the HCT-116 cells in a 24-well plate with a cell density of 250,000 cells per well. For transduction, supplement the HCT-116 media with 10μg/ml polybrene (MilliporeSigma #TR1003G). Add the virus to the wells and infect the cells by centrifuging at 1,200g and 32°C for 45 minutes.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"evian","text":" Blasticidin selection of HCT-116 cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"315dg","text":"24-hours post-transduction, remove the media containing the virus from the cells and exchange it for fresh media supplemented with 7.5μg/ml Blasticidin S HCI (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #A1113903) to start the 5-day selection.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"98nvb","text":"Selecting a target MOI.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6k6r3","text":"Depending on your transduction experiment, different multiplicities of infection (MOIs) may be required. For example, when transducing gRNA libraries, it is generally preferred to avoid multiple integrations within cells. Conversely, when aiming to generate stable Cas9-expressing cell lines, multiple integrations and a diverse population of cells with distinct integrations can be advantageous to prevent silencing of these constructs during passaging. We use the Poisson distribution to estimate the MOI that best suits the infection efficiency. For gRNA libraries, we typically aim for an MOI of 0.1, as this is estimated to result in only 0.5% of cells with multiple integrations. For the generation of stable cell lines, our target MOI is usually 1, where it is estimated that 63% of cells will have one or more integrations.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c6hu0","text":"Transduction for viral titration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43ss3","text":"For viral titration, follow the transduction protocol as outlined in step 13, \"Transducing HCT-116 cells,\" but double the cell number to transduce in a 6-well plate. Test various doses of filtered and concentrated viral supernatant to determine the concentration of virus required for your target MOI. Typically, we select six virus doses, ranging up to 1 milliliter, but this may vary (i.e. in microliters: 0, 10, 30, 60, 80, 250, 750).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77jkf","text":"Infect one 6-well plate with the virus of interest using the chosen doses and two 6-well plates (in duplicate) with a fluorescent virus (for example, Addgene, #85556), using the same virus doses. Additionally, include control wells, such as those containing only virus and no selection.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4picl","text":"Start selection of viral titration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"81cq8","text":"24-hours post-transduction, start the selection process on the plate containing the virus of interest and on one of the GFP virus plates.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2huab","text":"Quantify infection efficiency on the non-selected GFP Plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7nfom","text":"To quantify infection efficiency, use a flow cytometer (such as an Accuri or any other Cytoflex) and analyze the non-selecting GFP-virus plate. Measure the percentage of GFP-positive cells across the different wells infected with various concentrations of the GFP virus. Identify the well that most closely matches the target infection efficiency. For example, for an MOI of 0.1, select the well exhibiting approximately 10% GFP-positive cells (e.g., the well with 30µl of GFP virus).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"v72g","text":"Choose the dose of your virus of interest for your target MOI.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79d1d","text":"Five days post-selection, compare the GFP-selected well determined from the flow check (i.e., the 30µl well) to the wells containing the virus of interest. Select the virus of interest well that closely resembles the GFP-selected well. Confirm this choice by cell counting. For instance, if 30µl of unselected GFP virus resulted in a 10% infection efficiency and the 30µl well of the selected GFP virus closely resembled the 10µl well of the selected virus of interest, we opted for 10µl of the virus of interest for the actual experiment.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9h9fc","text":"Introduction to generating an inducible CRISPRi cell line.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":58}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4lupc","text":"To generate an HCT-116 CRISPRi inducible cell line we transduce HCT-116 cells as outlined in step 13, \"Transducing HCT-116 cells\".","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"409ef","text":"Integrating a tetracycline activator in HCT-116 cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":54}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9tmsn","text":"To introduce the tetracycline activator, transfect HCT116 cells with a plasmid expressing rtTA coupled to a neomycin resistance cassette (Takara, #631363). {"blocks":[{"key":"6q7n4","text":"Integrating the tetracycline operator-controlled CRISPRi machinery.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":67}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9en6m","text":"To integrate the inducible CRISPRi machinery, proceed by transducing the rtTA-positive cells with a construct expressing KRAB-dCas9 linked to BFP under a TRE3G promoter (Addgene, #85449). {"blocks":[{"key":"bhm26","text":"Generating single gRNA CRISPRi knockdown HCT-116 cell lines.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dt91a","text":"Prepare virus for your positive and negative control gRNAs (refer to step 26, 'Choosing and preparing gRNAs for validating the CRISPRi cell line') following the steps outlined in the 'Lentivirus preparation' section. {"blocks":[{"key":"cmqlt","text":"RNA extraction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37cmr","text":"To extract RNA from 5K-20K cells, begin by aliquoting 15µl per sample of MyONE SILANE (Thermo # 37002D) magnetic beads for the cleanup process. Remove the supernatant, then take the tube off the rack and resuspend the beads once in Buffer RLT (Qiagen). Place the tube back on the magnet, wait for the beads to separate, and discard the supernatant. Resuspend the beads in 5µl RLT per sample and add to 90µl of resuspended cells in RLT. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7bvgp","text":"Clean up the samples by adding 70µl RLT to each sample, mixing, and then adding 90µl isopropanol. {"blocks":[{"key":"8m9ph","text":"Reverse transcription.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8me7k","text":"For the Reverse Transcription process, begin by aliquoting 12.2 µl of RNA, denature it at 75°C for 3 minutes, and immediately place it on ice.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"frsl5","text":"Prepare the reverse transcription mix (volumes per sample):","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rmg0","text":"•\t1.2µl H2O","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqeto","text":"•\t0.8µl 100µM Random Hexamers","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29a6b","text":"•\t2µl 10x AffinityScript Buffer","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94f9k","text":"•\t2µl DTT (100mM)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1o0fd","text":"•\t0.8µl 100mM dNTP mix (25mM/base)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8mtqk","text":"•\t1µl AffinityScript RT enzyme","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ufog","text":"Add 7.8µl of the reverse transcription mix to the 12.2µl of RNA, and mix thoroughly by pipetting. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"akr0u","text":"Designing a gRNA library.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mm27","text":"Design a gRNA library to target the TSSs of your target genes, candidate enhancers, and negative controls. Candidate enhancers are typically DNase-seq peak peaks and can be selected using ABC enhancer-gene pair predictions or other criteria. For each genomic target specify a region of 500bp centered around the DNase-seq peak. Design the gRNAs to be tiled across each element by making a list of every possible target site with an NGG PAM sequence. Rank the target sites by calculating a specificity score based on potential off-target effects as previously described15. Remove target sites with a score \u003c20 and include up to 10-30 gRNAs per genomic target site (for FlowFISH screens, less for TAP-seq screens, i.e. 2-4). Add approximately 20% non-binding negative control sequences to your gRNA pool. And for cloning purposes add a ‘G’ to the 5’ end of every target sequence, unless already present.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":568,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cfinv","text":"Sequencing cloned gRNA library pools.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"794h8","text":"To determine even gRNA distribution in your cloned gRNA library pool, start by amplifying the purified library cloning product using sequencing primers that include an Illumina adapter sequence and an index sequence for multiplexing.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvh0p","text":"Sequencing forward primer: ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ltjr","text":"AATGATACGGCGACCACCGAGATCTACAC nnnnCGATTTCTTGGCTTTATATATCTTGTG","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"14ob8","text":"Sequencing reverse primer: ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ti4r","text":"CAAGCAGAAGACGGCATACGAGATnnnnnnnn ACAGTCGAGGCTGATCAGC","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb464","text":"Prepare the PCR mix:","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"deqea","text":"-\t20µl 2X Q5 Hot Start Master Mix (NEB)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ccdm","text":"-\t3µl Primer Mix (25 µM each)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cg17o","text":"-\t1µl purified library (1ng/µl)","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"47rb7","text":"-\t16µl H2O","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31ut7","text":"PCR amplify in two stages: 98°C 30 seconds; Run an aliquot of a gel to check the approximately 200bp-sized amplicon. Purify the PCR product twice with 1X AMPure XP beads and elute the final product in 15μl H2O.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"54he4","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ftbl","text":"Perform MiSeq sequencing aiming for 100-1,000 reads per gRNA in your pool and spike in the following custom primers:","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7mfdj","text":"Port 18 - Custom Read 1 primer: CGATTTCTTGGCTTTATATATCTTGTGGAAAGGACGAAACACCG","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d1r9q","text":"Port 19 - Custom Index 1 primer: AAGGCTAGTCCGTTATCAACTTGAAAAAGTGGCACCG","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tft7","text":"The gRNA sequence read-out and dual indexing strategy requires 21bp for Read 1, 8bp for Index 1, and 4bp for Index 2. Paired-end sequencing is not required.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ru9h","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2u68o","text":"Generate a text file containing each of your guide IDs and sequences on separate lines. Then, use Bowtie16 to generate \"genome\" files, treating the guide sequences as the genome. Subsequently, run Bowtie to identify exact matches for each guide and count the number of unique matches obtained for each guide. Calculate the library pool 'skew', which represents the difference in count frequency between the top and bottom 10th percentiles of guides. {"blocks":[{"key":"8l7q4","text":"Generating guide library expressing CRISPRi cell lines.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":55}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69k6r","text":"Prepare a lentivirus library following the ‘Lentivirus preparation’ section and titrate this library according to the ‘Virus titration’ section. Transduce the doxycycline-inducible CRISPRi HCT-116 cell line according to step 13, ‘Transducing HCT-116 cells‘ with the gRNA library aiming for an MOI of 0.1 and a coverage of 500 transduced cells for each gRNA (i.e. for 1,000 gRNAs start with a population of 5,000,000 cells for the transduction). After selection combine all transduced cells from individual wells to one large plate/flask and maintain them in 1/3 of the selection antibiotic concentration, (i.e. 2.5μg/ml Blasticidin) and at a 500X coverage of the gRNAs at all times to maintain library complexity and gRNA distribution (i.e. for 1,000 gRNAs this should be at least 500,000 cells post-selection).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"79rbs","text":"Induce CRISPRi machinery and target protein degradation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":56}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5s7n","text":"To conduct the CRUDO screens, expand the library pool of transduced cells to 50 million for each target gene. This number accounts for potential losses during harvesting, ensuring robust coverage. However, if your library pool exceeds 15,000 gRNAs, increase the number of cells to maintain a coverage of at least 500X for subsequent steps. Divide the 50 million cells into four flasks, each containing 10 million cells, with duplicates for each condition (replicate numbers can be adjusted as needed).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eckt4","text":"In each flask, activate CRISPRi expression by treating with 1μg/ml doxycycline (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #BP26531). After 18 hours of doxycycline treatment, add 500μM IAA (MilliporeSigma, #I37505GA) to two flasks per target gene to activate the targeted degradation of your protein of interest.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ej249","text":"Following 24 hours of treatment, harvest the cells according to step 7, 'Harvesting and passaging of cells' procedure, and proceed with your chosen read-out.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fp7kp","text":"Performing CRUDO-FlowFISH.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"739bh","text":"For a FlowFISH read-out of your CRUDO screen follow the steps as previously described11,17.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":85,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehdfk","text":"Briefly for each sample take 10 million of the harvested cells and stain each sample with the PrimeFlow RNA Assay Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, #88–18005 for the respective target gene with an Alexa Fluor 647 (AF647, ‘Type 1’) probeset and against for RPL13A to have a positive control housekeeping gene with Alexa Fluor 488 (AF488, ‘Type 4’). Use an Astrios EQ Sorter (i.e. Beckman Coulter, #B25982 or similar) and sort the cells into six bins based on the fluorescence intensity of the respective target gene. Normalize for staining efficiency. Then on the collected cells reverse-crosslink and extract the gDNA (i.e. 24 samples per gene: 2 conditions, 2 replicates, and 6 sorting bins). Finally, sequence the guide RNA integrations according to step 32,  ‘Sequencing cloned gRNA library pools’. Code for processing CRISPRi FlowFISH data is available at https://github.com/EngreitzLab/crispri-flowfish.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":857,"length":48}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"AEB57A4D258411EF9DA90A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/EngreitzLab/crispri-flowfish."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1gl67","text":"Performing CRUDO-TAPSeq.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5hpd","text":"For a TAP-seq read-out of your CRUDO screen adapt the previously described12 steps as follows:","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":74,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13p15","text":"Briefly, resuspend the harvested cells in PBS with 1% BSA (ThermoFisher #J65097.A1). Perform 10x encapsulation and barcoding following manufacturer’s instructions (10x Chromium Next GEM Single Cell 3’ GEM Kit v3.1) and load 16,000 cells per lane. The number of lanes required per sample depends on the number of gRNAs in your pool aim for 1,000 recovered cells for each gRNA. For instance, if your gRNA pool consists of 100 gRNAs you will want to recover 10,000 cells, which requires one 10x lane loaded with 16,000 cells (check the manufacturer's recommendations for cell recovery and cell loading numbers). Once the cDNA is obtained amplify your target gene set and gRNA library. First amplify the cDNA using a mix of Partial R1, Partial R1N, Partial TSO, and a mix of the TAP-seq outer primers. Then perform a size selection using AmpureXP beads to separate the gDNA and mRNA amplicons. Continue to amplify the gRNA amplicons using the Feature SI Primers 3 primers. Amplify the mRNA pool using Read 1 and a mix of the TAP-seq inner primers. After indexing sequenced the libraries aiming for 20,000 reads per cell for the mRNA and 2,000 reads per cell for the gRNA libraries. Code for processing TAP-seq data is available at https://github.com/argschwind/TAPseq_workflow.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1227,"length":46}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B9E3A3DD258411EF9DA90A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/argschwind/TAPseq_workflow."}}}}
